td.p: Johnston, John. Description of the Country around Lakes Superior and Huron, 1809. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0018

div.p: The coast from Grand Island to Carp River which is twelve leagues is only Remarkable for a constant interchange of of Rugged freestone Points and Sandy bays each of which has its little River, to all of which the Indians give names, 'tho the greater number will not admit a loaded Canoe, being choaked at the entrance with banks of Sand thrown up by the Lake, and are seldom navigable even for Small Canoes more than three or four leagues[.]

The coast from Carp River assumes quite a different form from that part of it already passed. The Mountains behind are conical and the Rocks appear a perfect Lava[.] About four miles from the River is the Peninsula which projects North East and is curious from being One half freestone and the Other Basaltes[.] The Indians find in the fissures of this last, a black Substance not unlike limestone which when pounded they put in a Small bag and boil it with any Stuff or yarn they wish to die black; the taint however is not bright tho lasting – the same quantity will serve many times without any apparent diminution of its Strength[.] About two miles east of the Peninsula there are Several high Rocks where the Indians Say there is copper[.] I visited them last Year and found them very different from any I had hitherto seen, they having in many places the appearance of metal but as I am no Mineralist I cannot presume to Say whether Really So or not[.] The water is extremely deep
